hobby.message: Antique typewriters and quiet bars — good pair.
You flying analog or digital FPV drones these days?
Is analog photography still worth the risk?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Path was clear enough. Not much to report, really.
Been spending evenings on my old typewriter. Keeps the mind occupied.
Recent disruptions have made quiet hobbies more appealing.
Best not to say too much these days.
Cautious walk, but no one stopped me.
Took a detour—habit from restoring antiques. Typewriters, mainly.
Tools laid out, careful where I store them now.
The latest utility limits made cleaning the keys a hassle.
Strange how even a hobby feels monitored lately.
Little tense out there. The routes keep changing, some surveillance near the squares.
Been repairing typewriters at home, keeps my hands steady.
Last week, restrictions delayed me getting parts.
It’s odd—remember when you could find a spare ribbon anywhere?
Now I keep most of it in my own drawer.
Sometimes the BCI even notices a late trip to the mailbox.
Strange sense to the street tonight—like everyone’s second-guessing their steps.
At home, I lose time to the old Underwood or Remington—restoring them piece by piece.
Last Saturday, utility checks nearly interrupted mid-repair.
I’ve started logging my restorations by hand—old habit, but safer.
Makes each page feel deliberate, given all the digital eyes lately.
Once, I’d invite neighbors to see the finished work. Now? Not so much.
Even a late-night ribbon change feels like something to be justified.
You know, the walk made me think how the city’s changed since all this BCI chaos.
These days, I retreat into those old typewriters. Restored over a dozen—each with a story from before the algorithms.
After Halden’s death, everything tightened. Even hobbies feel like little acts of defiance.
My journals, handwritten, are now more secret than ever. Small comfort.
Last week, I nearly triggered a service denial assembling parts—BCI flagged the package.
Sometimes I think the system remembers too much. A typewriter, though—remembers only what you want.
There’s relief in tapping keys at midnight, away from wireless eyes.
Even if it’s just ink and ribbon, it grants privacy they can’t touch.
hobby_answer: Still do, when I find the time.
Machines from a quieter era. Routine helps the days go by.
Past weeks, access to supplies has been more... restricted.
Too many rules lately, even for small things.
Everything gets noticed, even old hobbies.
Yes, I keep the old typewriters functional.
Complicated, now, with these building restrictions in place.
People notice when you take parts out of storage rooms.
During the demonstrations, I stayed clear of communal spaces.
No sense in drawing attention with odd habits.
Even a ribbon change can shift your score these days.
I still restore the typewriters, every chance I get.
Nothing like old steel and ink. Simple, honest work.
With the service disruptions lately, cleaning tools takes planning.
After that BCI leak, the laundry room is always booked or locked.
Had to adjust, use less water, schedule odd hours for repairs.
Sometimes I just listen to the protests through my window.
The world gets louder but my machines stay constant.
Yes, I’m still tinkering with my collection of old typewriters.
A few models survived the purges. I keep them working, quietly.
Latest unrest made supplies scarce—lubricant, ribbons, even paper.
Can’t use communal sinks after the new score thresholds.
Hard to explain ‘maintenance’ without it sounding strange now.
Sometimes the cleaning sounds draw curious eyes or security reviews.
I wait until late. Quiet, nobody around, just me and the Remington.
Odd, but taking care with small things keeps my mind steady.
Of course, I still tune them. Some habits go deeper than policy.
I started collecting pre-system, when people valued quiet work.
Now with laundry limits and BCI rules, every action gets noted.
A low score last week meant hours waiting just to clean a platen.
Part of me wonders if even these old devices will get flagged.
After Halden’s death, everything’s under suspicion—even hobbies like ours.
I hide my repair logs now, write in code, avoid syncs with the building hub.
There’s comfort in the slow repair, in keeping something alive by hand.
Strange world, Alex, when discretion is more vital than ink.
